content:
It was a fantastic weekend in LA at the Daytime Emmy Awards!

Sunday night's event honored the shows and the stars of daytime TV (and game shows) and the energy in the Pasadena Civic Auditorium was amazing.  What a great night for ABC, which won for best game show, best morning program and best daytime drama.  

On my way back now, and I'll see you tonight on Eyewitness News at 11.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content: Ryan's going to be terrific in this new role, don't you think?
name: NJ Burkett
title: Sandy Kenyon

content:
Newswriters are the glue that holds a newscast together.  The best of them provide the context that makes a story relevant, or the spark of wit that makes it resonate.  And they make anchors, reporters and show producers better than could ever be, on their own.  

I've been fortunate to have worked for many fine writers at Eyewitness News, but no one was more professional or more thoughtful or more thorough than Michael Lynn.  

Mike passed away, suddenly, while helping to write the newscast for Eyewitness News This Morning, early on Friday.  In fact, I was working that early morning, and learned Mike's news as I was heading to my assignment.  It's awful.  

I can hear his smooth, confident voice as clearly in my mind as if he were with me now, and I won't soon forget it.  Unflappable, that's how the man was.  

We had a long talk, just the two of us, after attending the wake for beloved Eyewitness News video editor Mary Lily, several months ago.  

"How much longer are you going to do this job?" he asked me.  I told him I didn't really know, and that I hadn't really thought all that much about doing anything else.  But Mary Lily's passing clearly gave him pause.  

"And you?" I asked.  "It certainly makes you think, doesn't it?" he answered.  Mike was 65.  I hope that his family knows how much he meant to all of us at Eyewitness News.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Timeline Photos

content:
If she had it to do over again, sixteen year-old Whitney Pierre-Paul admits she would have done it differently.  

She was just getting off the subway in Crown Heights with her two year-old brother, when a stranger accosted them and picked up the boy.  

She asked him to put the child down, but he refused and she says she was intimidated.  So rather than put up a fight, and fearing for the boy's safety, she allowed the man to walk to their building.  

Moments later, she became the victim of a push-in robbery.  And yes, she knows it could have been much worse.  

See you later tonight, on Eyewitness News at 11.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
The Oyster Bay Town Supervisor Joe Saladino crashes a news conference by residents furious over new cellphone towers that have quietly been installed in their neighborhoods.  

Promises to fight the FCC directive that allows companies to install the towers without municipal approvals.  

See you soon, on Eyewitness News First at 4PM tonight.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
So, you had questions for the company installing the small cellular networks on Long Island?  So did I.  

Here are some answers from Laura Jones, spokesperson for Crown Castle, the Houston-based wireless network architect which has  designed and installed six hundred of these mini towers in Nassau and Suffolk counties.   

Q:  What do the cell repeaters do and are they currently activated?  

A:  Crown Castle is the nation’s largest provider of wireless infrastructure. We design and operate network solutions to enhance broadband coverage and capacity. The technology in question is referred to as a small cell network, which is designed to provide a more targeted, specialized solution to provide the needed coverage and capacity. Unlike traditional towers, small cells are deployed on utility pole in the public right of way.  

Wireless devices today consume more and more data, due in large part to the capabilities and usefulness of the smartphone. While a mobile device may display full bars, calls can still drop and video streaming may not work properly. This happens when there is not enough network capacity to handle the volume of traffic in an area, at a particular time. 

Crown Castle’s systems are designed to enable enhanced network performance and avoid such issues, improving the experience for the smartphone use.  

The recently constructed locations for our small cell network are not currently activated.

Q:  What do the health data show about this technology?

A:  Crown Castle fully complies with all FCC regulations addressing the safety of this technology and we have submitted a report demonstrating compliance to the Town.  The wireless equipment to be used in the Town of Oyster Bay produces RF levels well below the FCC’s permitted maximums.

Q:  Why did they have to be placed in front of homes in a residential neighborhood?

A:  We use great care when considering where to place facilities in the public right of way and many factors are involved in the design, engineering and construction of our networks.  

Since 2016, we have worked continuously with the Town of Oyster Bay and the Department of Public Works on the design and location of the small cell network. During the process, Crown Castle voluntarily moved approximately half of the recently constructed locations at the Town’s request to best meet the needs of the community. The Town issued permits for this work in April 2017.   

 
Q:  How many towers have been installed in the counties of Nassau and Suffolk?

A:  The equipment in Oyster Bay is a small cell network, not towers.  Crown Castle has been working in the community for the last 8 years installed approximately 600 small cell across Long Island.

Q:  What is Crown Castle's reaction to the Town of Oyster Bay's rescinding the construction permits for cell towers in the town?  

A:  We have worked closely and continuously with the Town of Oyster Bay and have complied with all jurisdictional requirements. We will continue our efforts to bring the necessary improvements to the area.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
How long is the Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus train?  

I passed the train as it was rolling to Long Island this week and there were so many railcars I lost count!  60?  70?  Maybe 80 cars?  Wow.  

Tonight, Eyewitness News reporter CeFaan Kim gets to cover their final engagement at the Nassau Coliseum.  And, yes, I am jealous--but I'll still watch at 11PM!
name: NJ Burkett

content:
The 24 year-old woman in Monday's Bay Ridge attack shows me how she was grabbed in a headlock, with a gun jabbed in her abdomen, by thieves demanding money.  

After five days the young men remain at-large and the victim says she's terrified.  The NYPD has asked us to publicize the crime, hoping someone will recognize the men.  

See you soon, on Eyewitness News tonight at 11.

So, what did your mom give you?

At Sagamore Hill, the home of Theodore Roosevelt, America's twenty-sixth president, with WABC-TV photographer, Joe Tesauro.  

It was great to have a day off the street to produce a feature segment for Channel 7's annual special, "Kickoff to a Long Island Summer."  

The show airs on Memorial Day weekend, at 7PM Saturday.

content:
‪Richard Rojas is arrested, seconds after he plowed into a crowd of people in Times Square at noon today.  A young woman was killed; twenty-two were injured, some seriously.  

The cause is still not clear but authorities say it was likely not an act of terrorism.  Police say Rojas has prior arrests for DWI and appeared intoxicated at the time of the crash.  

The latest tonight, on Eyewitness News First at 4.
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

The driver was dragged from the scene, crazed and incoherent, after witnesses say he plowed into crowds of tourists in Times Square.  He apparently had no known political motive, but there are still many unanswered questions.  

Thursday's 6PM lead story.

content:
Security is stepped-up in Times Square, where witnesses say a crazed driver plowed into crowds of tourists. 

Mayor Bill de Blasio says the suspect had undiagnosed mental illness that went untreated, most likely, for several years.
name: NJ Burkett

content:
An MTA bus driver is maced by a passenger and the NYPD is hoping someone can identify the suspect.  

What led up to the attack is still not clear, but it happened just before 11PM on Friday night aboard the B15 bus in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.  

The suspect, a woman, was dressed from head to toe in black and wore a surgical mask.  

Details on Eyewitness News First at 4.

content:
It was the Summer White House before there was a summer White House.

Theodore Roosevelt, America's twenty-sixth president, lived in Oyster Bay from 1885 until his death in 1919 in a spectacular turn-of-the-century home he named Sagamore Hill.  

When the producers asked me to do a feature segment for Channel 7's annual special, "Kickoff to a Long Island Summer," I immediately suggested Sagamore Hill.  

T.R.'s outsized personality is all over the home, and I notice new things about it every time I visit.  

And the house sits on eighty-three acres of forest, meadows and salt marshes.  The nature trail leads to a secluded beach on Cold Spring Harbor, and I do that walk several times a year.  

WABC-TV photographer Joe Tesauro and I spent the day there, and you can see our segment on Saturday evening at 7PM.  And if you like it, make the trip!  

There's a fee for the guided house tour, but entrance to the grounds, the museum and the nature trail is free.  It's definitely one of my favorite places on Long Island.  

https://www.nps.gov/sahi/index.htm
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
On this Memorial Day, I am thinking of U. S. Army Capt John Robbins Burkett, who was killed by a German machinegunner on November 1, 1918.  Capt Burkett was my grandfather’s eldest brother.

Capt Burkett died during The Meuse-Argonne Offensive, the greatest American battle of the First World War. In six weeks, the Americans lost 26,277 men; over 120,000 were wounded. The battle is still the largest in both manpower and loss in American military history.

It was a very complex operation involving a majority of the ground forces fighting through rough, hilly terrain the German Army had spent four years fortifying. Its objective was the capture of the railroad hub at Sedan which would break the rail net supporting the German Army in France and Flanders and force the enemy's withdrawal from the occupied territories. 

The final action of the war began with a frontal attack heading north and east with the end goal of the Meuse River. The plan worked well. The Germans could not muster a strong defense as their army crumbled. Within three days, American troops had crossed the Meuse River and continued to press forward toward the city of Sedan. American forces stopped just short of taking the historic city. 

Capt Burkett was an attorney from Houston, Texas and the commander of the 90th Division, 1st Battalion, 359th Infantry, Company C. On November 1, 1918 he led his men on a dangerous but successful mission to seize a strategically crucial hilltop. He was struck with a single bullet just above his left eye by a German machinegunner, apparently while smoking a victory cigar. 

He was 27 years old, and died just ten days before the armistice. He is buried in Riverside Cemetery, Jackson, Tennessee. The American Legion Post in Houston bears his name. http://www.txlegionpost77.com/
name: NJ Burkett
title: Photos from NJ Burkett's post

content:
Sagamore Hill, Teddy Roosevelt's home in Oyster Bay, LI, was the original Summer White House.  And now?  A great summer daytrip! 

Here's my segment, from Saturday night's special, "Kickoff to a Long Island Summer."
name: NJ Burkett
title: A visit to Sagamore Hill
